lines.text: You may turn your back on Scaramouche, my lord, but surely you will not run away from Andre Moreau?
Scaramouche, you have just given your last performance.
[they fight]
Ah, diamonds!
I thought of your eyes and I went right out and bought them.
Just my eyes? How sweet - I must see that you start thinking about all of me.
Happy is the rascal, traveling life's byways, to whom the gods say, here is an easy switch. You may have lost Diana on the highway, but look, there is Aphrodite in a ditch.
I fall in love constantly, indiscriminately! The effect is the same as if I never fell in love at all.
Moreau! I can't see you!
You must be shortsighted. I am here.
I have your word as a man!
As a fiend incarnate!

[about a revolutionary pamphlet]
Well, what do you think of it?
Well, the grammar is appalling. On the first page you've doubled two negatives, split an infinitive and missed out three commas.
Negatives, infinitives, commas... he prattles punctuation while France is in agony!
I don't suppose you can mend a broken wheel?
Unfortunately not. A broken heart...
Oh, thank you, but might heart is quite intact.
I envy you. Mine is in chains from this moment.
Think of this. A sword is like a bird. If you clutch it too tightly, you choke it - too lightly and it flies away.
But who is Scaramouche? And why does he hide his face behind a mask?

[to De Maynes]
Yes, you're going to die, but not by a bullet. You're going to die as he died, by the sword. You'll be driven back, step by step, until you stand helpless, as he did. And then I, Andre Moreau, will kill you as you killed him. l swear it, Philippe, by all that I hold sacred. l swear you this man's death.

[during a play]
Good people of Lacrosse. Now, let me read you a letter from Paris."We, the management of the Prado Ghetta have the pleasure in offering an extended engagement to the Gaston Binet traveling troupe of players... featuring the sensational Scaramouche.
[he falls down a trapdoor]
Did anybody see an unpleasant man with a letter? A letter inviting Scaramouche to Paris? I need hardly say that Scaramouche stays here in Lacrosse!
I am angry with you, sir.
Angry, Your Majesty?
Very angry! You know why, of course.
Could it be for fighting Count de Talles?
Among others.
I only scratched him a little.
They say you crippled him for life.
And five minutes later, you killed the Baron Marblaux.
An unfortunate accident. He ran into my sword.
Are you mad?
We're all out of our minds, haven't you observed it?
Ah, my friend Chabrillaine. l know, my face. It reminds you of a bos taurus horrendus.
Huh? What's that?
An Ethiopian ox.

[fencing]
The head. Fight with the head, forget the heart. That's enough for today. Go home.
Thank you.
You have a demon in you, this fine day. Lose it or you'll not live to see another.
You believe in liberty. You know it's being strangled.
I also believe in laughter and I know the world is mad.
Deputy du Rouge, representing the Soissons district?
Mr. President, the deputy from Soissons will be absent from this assembly... permanently.

[attempting to challenge him to a duel]
My name is De Crillons from Château Thierry. Your face revolts me. Your eyes are pig's eyes, and your ears...
All right.
Behind the cathedral at six.
By all that I hold sacred, I swear you this man's death.
Your brain is gone! Where did you fall, on your head?
If you fidget, I may draw blood. You're making me nervous. Now where was I?
On second thought, I realize that I am very much interested in politics. And I would be proud to serve the people of France in their hour of need!
Forgive the intrusion, but vehicle ordinance number 4012 forbids osculation in public conveyances. First offenders get three days in the pillory.

[Exiting]
And now for the stuff that makes fools of princes and princes of fools - money!
Do you know who this is?
Scaramouche!
a man!
I can no longer be taught by the man who taught my enemy. So, what is more fitting in a mad world, then to be taught by the man who taught the man who taught my enemy!
Andre, you're dressed very oddly. Are you in trouble too?
Well, not yet, darling, but it threatens. I have a young lady downstairs in a coach with an itch to be married. She's made two attempts since breakfast and her temper is rising.
Why? Why? Before all the saints in heaven, why?
The oceans are full of fish and the heavens with stars. To contemplate one woman to the exclusion of all others may be for some men, but not for me.
'Scaramouche stays in LaCrosse!' How I hate you.
How I love you.
I'm not coming.
Then I shall come with you.
Come where with me?
To the ends of the earth if that's where you're going.
I'm going home, and that's half a mile.
Half a mile with you is as fifty leagues with Cleopatra.
I ought to be burned at the stake for loving you - burned to a cinder.
Take me to Paris.
No!
[She bites him]

[Written prologue]
He was born with the gift of laughter and a sense that the world was mad.
Andre, to escape the soldiers, enters a room of a theater off the street.

[Drunk]
Welcome friend! A hundred thousand welcomes!

[Listening to door]
Shh! Shh!
And 'shh' to you. A hundred thousand shh shh! What's your name?
[locks the door and doesn't answer]
Oh, it that so? Glasses own.
[Bows]
What's my name? Go ahead and ask me. Who am I?
[Dismisses him]
Oh. Your not interested. In that case, I shall introduce myself to myself. Do you know who this is?
[points to his mask]
Scaramouche. Scaramouche, yes, but who IS Scaramouche? And why does he hide his face behind a mask? You don't know?
[Shakes head]
Then I'll show you
[removes his mask]
Scaramouche. Scaramouche is... Scaramouche is...
[passes out]
Poor Andre.
Oh no, not 'poor Andre'. NEVER 'poor Andre'. If he finds and loses a father, falls in love with a maid, then discovers that the maid is his sister and all in the space of an hour. What of it?
Andre, what did she say when you told her?
I told her nothing, nor shall I. The old man kept his secret secure during his lifetime, let him take it with him to heaven. I'll not betray him.
Are all things clear to souls in paradise?
